qas.question: The term immunology is derived from a Latin word that means what?
What are the major organs of the immune system?

answers.text: thymus and bone marrow, and chief lymphatic tissues such as spleen, tonsils, lymph vessels, lymph nodes, adenoids, and liver

qas.question: Who originally discovered these parts of the immune system?
How do physicians study a patient's immune system organs in emergency situations?

answers.text: surgically excised for examination while patients are still alive

qas.question: Which portions of the immune system can be safely removed in these emergency cases?

answers.text: thymus, spleen, bone marrow, lymph nodes and other lymphatic tissues

context: Prior to the designation of immunity from the etymological root immunis, which is Latin for "<a0_0>exempt<a0_0/>"; <a2_0>early physicians<a2_0/> characterized organs that would later be proven as essential components of the immune system. The important lymphoid organs of the immune system are the <a1_0>thymus and bone marrow, and chief lymphatic tissues such as spleen, tonsils, lymph vessels, lymph nodes, adenoids, and liver<a1_0/>. When health conditions worsen to emergency status, portions of immune system organs including the <a4_0>thymus, spleen, bone marrow, lymph nodes and other lymphatic tissues<a4_0/> can be <a3_0>surgically excised for examination while patients are still alive<a3_0/>.
